I have developed much of my life to poker AI over the last year and half
an=
d, much as in other areas of AI and EC (evo comp), have been severely
humbl=
ed. I started out with grandiose ideas like the ones you have below and
end=
ed up happy if I could get an agent that was as smart enough to not fold
wi=
th pocket aces. :-)

That's an exaggeration, of course, but--to my endless =
chagrin--not by too
much. 

Nevertheless, I would love to see someone pull =
of a neural network that
learns to play poker well, even if it also uses a =
set of rules to get it
within range of great play. Most of the people I kno=
w who work on poker AI
can't even get complicated expert systems/rule engin=
es to play poker well.
There is periodic talk of using neural nets, or EC, =
but no one seems to get
very far with it. I myself tried some machine learn=
ing techniques and found
it very hard to find a good representation of an i=
ndividual hand of betting
history, let alone variable size windows into pre=
vious hands.

In short, I'd love to see what you come up with as I do not y=
et know of
anyone who has had much luck with this. I also have not scoured =
the
literature. Do you know of other papers where NNs learned to play decen=
t
poker?



Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State Unive=
rsity
Visiting Scholar, Instituto de Biolog=EDa Molecular y Celular de Plan=
tas,
Valencia, Spain

jclune@...
34 679 921 530  (mobile in spain)




=
> From: tansey4 <tansey4@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <nea=
t@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Tue, 13 Feb 2007 19:37:06 -0000
> To: "neat@yaho=
ogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Questions about NEAT =
for poker
> 
> Hi all,
> 
> I'm a grad student at Virginia Tech and I would=
 like to enter a bot
> into the AAAI poker competition in July.  I've been =
working on poker
> AI in my spare time for the last 3 years.  I've looked a=
t a lot of the
> Alberta group's work and talked to most of them at last ye=
ar's AAAI
> competition.
> 
> My general plan is to use KB-NEAT and a set o=
f controllers + variables
> to evolve a network for rapid player modeling a=
nd exploitation in
> limit (and possibly no-limit) Hold Em.
> 
> A lot of t=
he knowledge in poker is very explicit with little
> exceptions.  For insta=
nce, "cap with the nut flush" (i.e. never stop
> raising) is a perfect exam=
ple of a piece of advice that works in 80%
> of cases, but certain situatio=
ns, like the board being paired,
> invalidate that advice.  I hope to help =
kick-start the learning
> process by developing a fairly in-depth set of ad=
vice rules.
> 
> My bot will also deviate from the normal approach of game_=
state ->
> atomic action (e.g., fold/call/raise).  Instead I'm going to hav=
e the
> bot select a "play" at the start of each round.  I define a play as=
 a
> set of betting actions that handle any case in the current round.  An
=
> example post-flop play (from first position) would be
> Check-Raise-Call.=
  Here, there is no way that the bot could ever reach
> a situation where i=
t doesn't know what to do.
> 
> I chose to use plays for two reasons.  Firs=
t, they simplify the input
> to the network as you do not have to consider =
the sequence of bets.
> Second, I believe that most (non-novice) human play=
ers actually use a
> similar--or even higher level-- model when playing.  F=
or instance,
> good players no-limit players (and to a lesser extent, limit=
 players)
> will often play a single hand in a loose fashion (usually attem=
pting a
> large bluff), hoping that the next hand will give them a similar
=
> situation but with a legitimate hand.  In such cases, players are
> actua=
lly planning on making the bluffs and subsequent big hands well
> ahead of =
time.  The evidence for this should be the speed with which
> most limit ri=
ng games are played.  As the stakes rise, the speed of
> the game tends to =
increase, as players create more abstract plays.
> 
> The inputs for my net=
works will be broken down into three main
> categories: betting, stats, and=
 history.  Betting will simply be a
> represenation of the previous rounds'=
 bet history.  Stats will
> encompass things like hand strength vs a random=
 player, flush draw
> probability, etc.
> 
> History will be a set of playe=
r statistics broken into 3
> sub-categories: total, previous hand, and a va=
riable range.  The
> statistics for each category will all be the same, wit=
h only the
> sample size varying.  Total will encompass the entire play his=
tory of
> the opponent.  Previous hand will look only at the previous hand.=

> Variable range will use the play over the previous N hands (where N <
> =
30).  This way I hope to be able to model players that quickly change
> the=
ir play.
> 
> I have a few questions:
> 
> 1) Is there a way I can use mult=
iple networks per individual in the
> population?  I.e., I want to have a s=
eparate network for each round,
> since there are different inputs (cards, =
bets) for each successive
> round.  I have considered making one monolithic=
 network and using
> extra nodes to represent on/off status of the round-sp=
ecific data, but
> I feel like that would add a lot of needless noise to th=
e network.
> 
> 2) This is related to 1, but is there any way to also encor=
porate
> other variables in my evolution parameters?
> 
> 3) Is there any c=
ode available for the KB-NEAT so I can incorporate my
> custom advice?
> 
>=
 
> If anyone is interested in a more detailed description of the inputs,
>=
 let me know.
> 
> 
> Wesley
>
